introduction.p: This information will help you decide which Math class you’re prepared to take at JU. (Different majors require different courses, so you’ll want to consult with your advisor and/or the catalog to see what you’ll eventually need to take. This page helps you figure out where you’re ready to enter the math curriculum at JU.) There are 4 different levels you could start at; use the information below to decide which is right for you.
As a guide to helping understand whether they have these skills, students entering Core-Level Math Classes should be able to successfully complete the problems listed here: Core-Level Problems.
Students who don’t feel they’d be successful in MATH 104 should start in MATH 100: Basic College Mathematics instead.
If you’re still not sure which math class is right for you, consult with your advisor or reach out to the mathematics department.

section.title: Math 140 Problems
section.p: Students entering Math 140 should be able to successfuly complete the problems below.

statement.p: If f(x)=16x-x^2, what is the area of the rectangle A?

solution.p: The area is length times height, so f(4)\cdot 4 = (16(4)-4^2)\cdot 4 = (64-16)\cdot 4 = 192

statement.p: Let h(x)=e^{3x+7}. Find functions f and g so that h(x)=f(g(x)).
Let C=f(A) be the cost in dollars of purchasing a plot of land of area A square feet. What do the quantities f(5000) and f^{-1}(250,000) represent?

solution.p: The quantity f(5000) is the cost (in dollars) of purchasing a plot of land of area 5000 square feet.
The quantity f^{-1}(250,000) is the area (in square feet) of a plot of land that you can purchase for 250,000 dollars.

statement.p:
Let f(x)=\dfrac{x^3-9x}{2x^3-6x^2}.
Identify the locations of the discontinuities of f(x) and classify them as holes or the location of a vertical asymptote.
Analyze the end behavior of f. That is, what happens as x goes towards \infty or -\infty?

li.p: First factor the denominator of f(x): 2x^3-6x^2=2x^2(x-3). The denominator equals 0 when x=0 or x=3, so those are the locations of the discontinuities.

To classify them, we factor the numerator as well and cancel where possible: x^3-9x=x(x^2-9)=x(x-3)(x+3). So \frac{x(x-3)(x+3)}{2x^2(x-3)}=\frac{x+3}{2x}. Since x-3 is no longer in the denominator after canceling, x=3 is a hole in the graph. Since x is still in the denominator, x=0 is a vertical asymptote of the graph.

ol.li: In the long run, f behaves like y=\dfrac{x^3}{2x^3}=\dfrac{1}{2}. That is, the graph has a horizontal asymptote of y=\frac{1}{2} to both the left and right.

statement.p: The enrollment at JU is given by the following graph of a linear function, where S represents the number of students and t represents the number of years since the year 2000.

ol.li: Using the two given points on the graph, determine the rate of change (slope) of the linear function.
How many students were there in the year 2000?
Determine a formula for S as a function of t.

The slope is found by computing rise over run using the given points:
\text{slope} = \frac{2744-2636}{4-1} = \frac{108}{3} = 36 .
The year 2000 corresponds to t=0, so we want the S-intercept of the line, which is 2600 students.
We know the slope and intercept of the line, so we use slope-intercept form: S(t) = 36t + 2600.

statement.p:
Without using a calculator, match each formula to a graph.
P=20(1.02)^t
P=20(0.98)^t
P=20(0.96)^t
P=20(1.04)^t

solution.p: From top to bottom, the graphs are (d), (a), (b), (c).

statement.p: Suppose the population of a certain small country is given by P(t)=19.5e^{0.01t}, where P is the population in millions, t years after the year 2000. Calculate and describe the meaning of P(8). Include units in your answer.

solution.p:
P(8)=19.5e^{0.01(8)}\approx 43.398 \text{ million people}
This means that in the year 2008, the population of the small country was approximately 43.398 million people (43,398,000 people).

statement.p:
The rabbit population in a national park rises and falls each year. The population is at its minimum number of rabbits at the beginning of January and increases in size to its maximum at the beginning of July. The population P of rabbits (in thousands) t months after January 1 is given by P(t)=-5\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{6}t\right) + 10.
What is the maximum population of rabbits each year? What is the minimum population of rabbits each year?

section.title: Core-Level Math Classes Problems
section.p: Students entering a Core-level Math class should be able to successfuly complete the problems below.

statement.p: The sophomore class of two different schools were surveyed. The following results show the declared majors.

ol.li: What percentage of sophomore students in School A major in Business?
Which school has a higher percentage of sophomore students who major in Nursing?
The total number of sophomore students in School A is 315. So the fraction majoring in business is \dfrac{155}{315}=0.492 and the percentage is 49.2\%.

li.p: School A has 315 students and School B has 1225 students.
So School A has a higher percentage of sophomore students who major in Nursing.

statement.p: Find an equation for the line passing through the points (-2,5) and (4,-3).

solution.p: We first find the slope of the line, which is m=\frac{-3-5}{4-(-2)}= \frac{-8}{6}=-\frac{4}{3}. Using point-slope form with the point (-2,5) and the slope m=-\dfrac{4}{3}, the line has equation y-5=-\frac{4}{3}(x+2).
Additional correct answers include y+3=-\frac{4}{3}(x-4) and y=-\frac{4}{3}x+\frac{7}{3}.

section.title: Math 104 Problems
section.p: Students entering Math 104 should be able to successfuly complete the problems below.

statement.p:
Use the polynomial 5x+2x^2y-4y to complete the following parts.
Identity the constant and variables for the term with the largest degree in the polynomial.
Given that x=4 and y=-\dfrac{1}{4}, evaluate the polynomial expression.

Consider the linear equation 4x-3y+12=0.
Solve the equation for y.
Use the equation to complete the following table:
x
y
-6
4
3
Give the coordinates of the points found in part b., and then plot the points and graph the linear equation.

ol.li: The points are (-6,-4), (0,4), and (3,8). The points and linear equation are graphed below.

statement.p:
In a classroom of 25 students, 3 are left-handed and 22 are right-handed.
What proportion of the class is left-handed?
Write the proportion found in part a as a percentage.
What is the ratio of left-handed students to right-handed students?
